SECRET.Referred to Committee of Home AffairsTHE CABINET.PREVENTION OF FRAUD (GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS) ^-BILL. 5452MEMORANDUM BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR WAR.I circulate for the approval of the Cabinet a draft Bill embodying in a statutory form the provisions of Regulation 45 (1) (h) of the Defence of the Realm Regulations.This Regulation provides that a person will be guilty of an offence who makes any statement, or does any act, intended or calculated to mislead or deceive any person in the employment of the Government as to the quantity or quality of any war material or other goods, or otherwise in relation to the manufacture, testing or supply thereof, or with the like intent withholds any information in his possession. This particular Regulation was found extremely useful during the War, and there have been a number of instances of successful prosecution. These offences were of a character highly dangerous to the lives of numbers of His Majesty s Forces ; for example, the insertion of faulty parts into aeroplanes. Prior to the Regulation being brought into operation, no adequate safeguards existed against fraudulent action on the part of contractors or - their employees in deceiving Government Inspectors as to the quality of stores produced. The Bill, as drafted, provides also against fraud in connection with services rendered.The continuance of this Regulation by the War Emergency Laws (Continuance) Act was secured with a view to the subject being dealt with by permanent legislation. It may be added that Mr. Guy Stephenson, the Assistant Director of Public Prosecutions, who has had much experience of'the difficulty of successfully instituting criminal proceedings in cases, now covered by Regulation 45 (1) (A), which arose before the War, strongly recommends that the Regulation should be kept alive in the form of permanent legislation, and it is at his suggestion that the present Bill has been drawn to apply to any goods and not merely, like the Regulation, to war material.W S 0The Wae Office, , ' '23rd July, 1920.i(B20/264) 100 7/20 HAS 8275wo [10 & 11 Geo. 5.] Prevention of Frauds (government contracts).DRAFT or aB I L LFORThe better Prevention of Frauds in relation to the supply of Goods or the rendering of services to His Majesty's Government, or to the Government of any part of His Majesty's Dominions, or of any territory under His Majesty's protection or over which the Government of any of His Majesty's Dominions exercises authority.BE it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows: 5 1. (b) with intent to mislead or deceive, or in any mannercalculated to mislead or deceive, withholds from any person employed or acting as aforesaid, any information in his possession with respect to any such goods or services, such person shall be liable on conviction on indictment to penal servitude for a term not exceeding three years, or on summary conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months, or to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds, or to both such imprisonment and fine. 10(2) "Where the person convicted under this section is a company, the chairman and every managing director and every officer concerned in the management of the company shall be guilty of a like offence, unless he proves that the offence took place without his knowledge or without his consent. 152. This Act may be cited as the Prevention of Prauds (Government Contracts) Act, 1920.
